messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chokuto
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Matt, that is certainly possible. The material encrusting the blade seems the same as what coats the tsuba, and a decoration on the end of the mekugi, so I
messages.messageBody:
Hi Matt, that is certainly possible. The material encrusting the blade seems
the same as what coats the tsuba, and a decoration on the end of the mekugi,
so I am not sure either way. Unfortunately this is not one of those early
swords that can be partially polished... the corrosion is too thorough, so I have
no problem with leaving the sword in its current condition...

In a message dated 8/23/2004 4:08:22 PM Eastern Daylight Time,
matthewhoyle@... writes:

> The dirt might actually be the remnants of the scabbard, or is that not
> possible?
>
> If this is the case, I would be inclined to leave it as is, but I really do
> not know anything about this stuff :-)
>
> Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chokuto
messages.msgSnippet: hello ray wow that is a very interesting find.might i suggest you contact scott rodell at seven stars trading co. he knows a bit about korean and chinese
messages.messageBody:
hello ray
wow that is a very interesting find.might i suggest you contact scott rodell at seven stars trading co. he knows a bit about korean and chinese blades and have known to come across a few.here is the link to his site and contact info.i have had several conversations with him about antique chinese blades and korean blades.he is a very friendly helpful guy. link: http://www.sevenstarstrading.com/

john white

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chokuto
messages.msgSnippet: The dirt might actually be the remnants of the scabbard, or is that not possible? If this is the case, I would be inclined to leave it as is, but I really do
messages.messageBody:
The dirt might actually be the remnants of the scabbard, or is that not
possible?

If this is the case, I would be inclined to leave it as is, but I really do
not know anything about this stuff :-)

Matt

messages.subject: Chokuto
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have been visiting with my future in-laws in Korea this past week and while there, made an interesting antique-shop find. This sword in question
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, I have been visiting with my future in-laws in Korea this
past week and while there, made an interesting antique-shop find.
This sword in question appears to be an old chokuto. From what I can
see under the corrosion and layers of soil, it is a straight, single-
edged iron blade with a nakago that ends in a half-ana. There are 2
other mekugi-ana with iron mekugi and the remnant of a copper fitting
where a fuchi would be located. The sword has a plain, round iron
tsuba with no sukashi. The question I have is, what if any
preservation should be done for this sword? The condition is very
fragile and I am not even inclined to brush off the surface dirt on
this piece. Any help is greatly appreciated...

http://www.sweetpumpkin.co.kr/Images/Chokuto1.jpg

http://www.sweetpumpkin.co.kr/Images/Chokuto2.jpg

http://www.sweetpumpkin.co.kr/Images/Chokuto3.jpg

http://www.sweetpumpkin.co.kr/Images/Chokuto4.jpg

Kind regards,
Ray Singer
